Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Carlow Chamber have serious concerns on the direction of Carlow Town and following public meetings many areas need to be addressed.  Presentation of the public realm, derelict buildings/vacant units, attracting business are some of the areas under discussion and that need attention.
DPOs Lobbied: Anne Ahern|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Cassin|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Jim Deane|Councillor|Carlow County Council::William Paton|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Pender|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Fintan Phelan|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Murphy|Councillor|Carlow County Council::William Quinn|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Fergal Browne|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Walter Lacey|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Brian O'Donoghue|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Ken Murnane|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Pat Deering|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Carlow Chamber have serious concerns on the direction of Carlow Town and following public meetings many areas need to be addressed.  Presentation of the public realm, derelict buildings/vacant units, attracting business are some of the areas under discussion and that need attention.
Intended Results: The Councillors must work as a collective to help reverse the current situation in Carlow town.  The Chamber have established the Love Carlow Task force and the inclusion and involvement of all stakeholders is vital.  The Cllrs must be made aware of what is happening and they must focus on working to ensure the correct resources are allocated to deal with the issues, budgetary challenges must be delivered and suggestions and involvement is imperative.
Lobbying Activities: Meeting held in Carlow Shopping Centre|Meeting|1::E-mail issued in relation to the meeting and also follow up e-mails issued after the meeting reviewing the areas covered|Email|2-5::Phone Calls to representatives in setting up the meeting and the importance of what the objectives of the meeting are.|Phone call|2-5
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Yvonne Jones, Derek Shannon, John Brophy, PJ Hickson, Eoin Kehoe

Lobbyist Name: Carlow Regional Youth Services Ltd
Specific Details: Deaths of two 14 yr old young males in Carlow and the resulting difficulties in accessing youth mental health supports for young people  in Carlow and insufficient funding for out of school counselling supports for Folliane Youth Counselling Service CRYS
DPOs Lobbied: Fintan Phelan|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Pat Deering|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Katherine Zappone|Minister|Department of Children and Youth Affairs::Kathleen Funchion|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|Senator|Seanad
Subject Matter: Deaths of two 14 yr old young males in Carlow and the resulting difficulties in accessing youth mental health supports for young people  in Carlow and insufficient funding for out of school counselling supports for Folliane Youth Counselling Service CRYS
Intended Results: Better co-ordination of and improved access to youth mental health supports and increased funding for Follaine Youth Counselling Service
Lobbying Activities:
Met with Local TD Pat Deering in June in Montgomery House to highlight crisis in relation to accessing supports for young people in light of recent suicides - Dail question submitted as a result and to request a meeting with Minister Helen McEntee
Met with Kathleen Funchion TD once in the Vault Youth Centre, 20th June, 2016, to highlight issues and request meeting with Minister for Children an Youth Affairs Katherine Zappone
Met with Senator Jennifer Murnane, 12th July, 2016,  to discuss issues and to request response from Simon Harris Minister for Health
Met with local councillor Fintan Phelan, July 2016 who brought issue to Carlow County Council and wrote to TUSLA CEO Fred McBride re lack of supports for young people under 16 who self harm|Meeting|2-5::Wrote to Marie Kennedy, TUSLA, at various points during summer,  requesting a meeting to discuss current situation and look at possible solutions
Wrote to Gerry Raleigh, NOSP, highlighting current situation and looking for support
Wrote to Aileen Colley, Chief Officer HSE, highlighting current situation and requesting a meeting, 
Wrote to Tracey Nugent, Suicide Prevention Officer, HSE, highlighting current situation and looking for additional support|Email|6-10::Met with Minister Helen McEntee in the Vault Youth Centre on 8th July to highlight issues, request additional funding and offer possible solutions to problems.  Marie Kennedy TUSLA and Elizabeth Charles NEPS were present.  Meeting also attended by Declan Callan Chairperson CRYS, Elaine Rowe Vice Chairperson, Leighann Ryan Senior Youth  Worker and Kathryn Wall|Meeting|1::Met with Aileen Colley and her Staff to discuss current situation and to discuss solutions, meeting took place in HSE Lacken, Kilkenny on Monday 4th July.  Elizabeth Charles NEPS attended and CRYS reps were Mary Doyle and Elaine Rowe Board Members and Leighann Ryan and Kathryn Wall CRYS|Meeting|1

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: The County Carlow Chamber are working with businesses and communities across Carlow in a number of ways towards bringing Carlow back on line following the COVID-19 pandemic.  The Chamber are conducting a Consumer Sentiment Survey to asssit in shaping the response from Businesses and the dirfection on what needs to be done across our towns and communities.
DPOs Lobbied: Fergal Browne|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Cassin|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Michael Doran|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Andy Gladney|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Thomas Kinsella|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Arthur McDonald|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Brian O'Donoghue|Councillor|Carlow County Council::William Paton|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Pender|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Fintan Phelan|Councillor|Carlow County Council::William Quinn|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Andrea Dalton|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Charlie Murphy|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John Murphy|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Tom O'Neill|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Adrienne Wallace|Councillor|Carlow County Council::John McDonald|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Ken Murnane|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: The County Carlow Chamber are working with businesses and communities across Carlow in a number of ways towards bringing Carlow back on line following the COVID-19 pandemic.  The Chamber are conducting a Consumer Sentiment Survey to asssit in shaping the response from Businesses and the dirfection on what needs to be done across our towns and communities.
Intended Results: The Consumer Sentiments Survey is about listening to the views of people who live, work, shop and play across Carlow.  We asked the elected officials to share their views and also to share the detials of the survey with their contacts/consitutents to ensure that everyone has the opportunity to add their voice to the story.

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: SME’s need to see dramatic financial intervention to support them while they continue trading to ensure they are able to retail jobs and are strengthened through the current crisis and the impending Brexit. While we are working through a tough time at present, we believe that 2021 will be even more challenging as the impacts of Brexit are felt and as many businesses will be back to operating without the supports that many are availaing of in the curreent crisis, act now or we will pay in future
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: SME’s need to see dramatic financial intervention to support them while they continue trading to ensure they are able to retail jobs and are strengthened through the current crisis and the impending Brexit. While we are working through a tough time at present, we believe that 2021 will be even more challenging as the impacts of Brexit are felt and as many businesses will be back to operating without the supports that many are availaing of in the curreent crisis, act now or we will pay in future
Intended Results: o	If jobs are to be saved, if businesses are to stay trading, we need to see certainty and clarity on the longer-term economic supports so that businesses can plan for their future. These supports need to address liquidity and cover overheads. Otherwise debt, which is mounting for many businesses, will sink them::At minimum, this will need to include a year-long waiver for impacted business from Commercial Rates, additional funding for Local Authorities, expanded grant aid, and a targeted extension of the Wage Subsidy Scheme for the greater part of the remainder of 2020

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Given the current crisis, while supports and grants are there to supoprt businesses and communities, we need to ensure that we look beyond these and consider the bigger picture
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Given the current crisis, while supports and grants are there to supoprt businesses and communities, we need to ensure that we look beyond these and consider the bigger picture
Intended Results: Investment in infrastructure and housing must be the centrepiece of the recovery, town centres will be at the heart of our economic recovery, if they are not – we are looking into a decade of stunted growth.  If the pursuit of regional development, job creation and more sustainable local economies is to have any chance of success, there must be a realistically resourced commitment to its delivery.

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: The Gov announced restrictions on the counties of Kildare, Laois and Offaly that impacted on businesses and communities in various ways.  The boundary between Carlow and Laois, running through Graigcullen impacts busienss with some like the Talbot Hotel Carlow being required to close due to the fact that it is just over the boundary line and pays rates to Laois, despite its main economic area being the greater Carlow area.
DPOs Lobbied: Ken Murnane|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Tom O'Neill|Councillor|Carlow County Council::Michael Brennan|Director of Services or Equivalent|Carlow County Council::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: The Gov announced restrictions on the counties of Kildare, Laois and Offaly that impacted on businesses and communities in various ways.  The boundary between Carlow and Laois, running through Graigcullen impacts busienss with some like the Talbot Hotel Carlow being required to close due to the fact that it is just over the boundary line and pays rates to Laois, despite its main economic area being the greater Carlow area.
Intended Results: Ascertain where the boundary line is and see what measures could be implemented to allow impacted businesses located in the area to continue operations::Review the possibliity of establishing a perimiter that would allow the busiensses in the area who are all serving the greater Carlow area to reamin in operation.  The Graiguecullen area is distanced from the impacted areas and is seamlesly connected to Carlow town.

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: The criteria on the EWSS programme need to be reviewed as they are restrictive and not supportive to business in the challenging COVID times
DPOs Lobbied: Kathleen Funchion|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: The criteria on the EWSS programme need to be reviewed as they are restrictive and not supportive to business in the challenging COVID times
Intended Results: The current programme is based on comparing trading levels against the same period in 2019.  As many retail business experienced a higher than normal trade in the July August period due to the earlier restrictions and also due to the fact that the period is traditionally slower due to holidays, this means many businesses are not in a position to avail of the support::The criteria needs to be reviewed and it is vital that other measures are taken into consideration.::There needs to be a proper mechanism for appeal and review of businesses that are in need of the support but are falling outside the criteria that is restrictive
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Proper communication is key to businesses success and it is imperative that the government, its agents and agencies ensure that there is clear, timely and concise messages to ensure we can get through teh pandemic together
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Proper communication is key to businesses success and it is imperative that the government, its agents and agencies ensure that there is clear, timely and concise messages to ensure we can get through teh pandemic together
Intended Results: The messages need to be communicated in a timely manner to ensue that businesses have the information needed to plan and implement the necessary changes::The government introduced a 5 stage plan, which then has modifications at all levels.  This means that it cannot be easily followed and planned for as all aspects are changing all the time.  Businesses owners and operators are responsible and professional people, the government should release/set parameters  to allow people clearly see and identity potential changes::It is frustrating for businesses that there is such fractured messages and communication coming from government
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Dereliction is a major issues in towns and needs the support of Government to be addressed
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Dereliction is a major issues in towns and needs the support of Government to be addressed
Intended Results: The planning system is cumbersome and not working properly, there needs to be a review of the system and ensure that it can work to support and address the challenges::The costs to bring many of units in above retail space locations do not make it viable for owners to being the units back to use::It is important that Government looks at legislation to support and encourage more people to be living in the town centres
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Commercial rates and supports into 2021 for businesses impacted by the pandemic and also Brexit
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas::Kathleen Funchion|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Commercial rates and supports into 2021 for businesses impacted by the pandemic and also Brexit
Intended Results: The waiver on Commercial rates that was introduced and provided 9 months relief to businesses in 2020 needs to be extended into the first quarter of 2021 at the minimum.  The challenges from COVID will remain and perhaps be stronger following Christmas and that coupled with the impacts of Brexit from 1st January are going to cause further challenges.::Applying a waiver to commercial rates for the first quarter of 2021 will allow businesses to focus on the challenges and should help us to get more businesses through to a stronger position::The funding to local government must be covered to ensure that services to businesses and communities are not affected
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Project Carlow 2040 - A Vision for Regeneration and the current funding applications that have been submitted by the council, it is imperative that the plan is highlighted at the highest levels and supported to ensure it moves forward.
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Project Carlow 2040 - A Vision for Regeneration and the current funding applications that have been submitted by the council, it is imperative that the plan is highlighted at the highest levels and supported to ensure it moves forward.
Intended Results: The Plan has been developed in consultation with various stakeholders and it is key that it has wide ranging support to ensure it is delivered for the businesses and communities of Carlow::It is vital that local issues are being fed up the channels to national government level through the network of T.D's in the constituency::Given the history of the Council in moving plans forward over the years, it is vital that all stakeholders and representatives are focused on helping to driver this plan forward and ensure it becomes a reality.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: Carlow Town Centre, issues concerning vacancy, dereliction, utilisation of space
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: Carlow Town Centre, issues concerning vacancy, dereliction, utilisation of space
Intended Results: If the vacant space was brought back to residential use, it woudl be a big step towards aleviating the issues of the housing crisis across the county and would also have a strong economic impact on the town centres and their viability.  Government needs to address this and put measures in place to support the reuse of this space::There needs to be some proactive work towards dealing with dereliction in the town and how we can bring spaces back into use.  The current cost of bringing above retail spaces back to use is prohibitive::The planning system needs to be reviewed in line with the issues of vacancy and dereliction to see how we can overcome the barriers that exist in the system, preventing property owners from converting property back to use.::While all the planning guidelines are coming centrally, we need to ensure that they can consider and support local issues and challenges
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell, Colin Duggan, Rowena Dooley,

Businesses in Graiguecullen are told to go to Portlaoise when services are on their doorstep in Calrow::While the boundary review commission did conduct review of the boundary in recent years, there needs to be more flexibility

Lobbyist Name: Delta Centre
Specific Details: challenges facing Section HSE funded 39 organizations  including inflation costs verses salaries of employees in Section 39 agencies, resulting in major issues in recruitment and retention of staff which in turn has potential negative impact on the quality services to people with disabilities
DPOs Lobbied: Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: challenges facing Section HSE funded 39 organizations  including inflation costs verses salaries of employees in Section 39 agencies, resulting in major issues in recruitment and retention of staff which in turn has potential negative impact on the quality services to people with disabilities
Intended Results: Additional funding to meet the inflationary costs facing services::pay parity for Section 39 agencies in relation to staff salaries and terms and conditions
Lobbying Activities: There was one meeting in Delta Centre on the 11th of July attended by Delta Centre CEO Joe Meany and Jennifer Murnane TD as well as two other service providers from the Carlow Area. The purpose of the meeting was to fully inform the government of the challenges facing Section 39 agencies in relation  to the current inflationary environment, and the ongoing challenges regarding recruitment and retention of staff   in Section 39 agencies which is exasperated by the disparity in salaries and terms/conditions between Section 39 agencies and Section 38 agencies / HSE|Meeting|1

Lobbyist Name: County Carlow Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Tourism CLG
Specific Details: AML issues impacting Gift cards - There is an exemption currently in place in relation to low-value emoney products like gift cards and it is potentially due to expire, this could have major consequences for gift cards and the wider industry
DPOs Lobbied: Michael McGrath|Minister|Department of Public Expenditure and Reform::Jennifer Murnane O'Connor|TD|Dáil Éireann, the Oireachtas
Subject Matter: AML issues impacting Gift cards - There is an exemption currently in place in relation to low-value emoney products like gift cards and it is potentially due to expire, this could have major consequences for gift cards and the wider industry
Intended Results: The European Parliament were scheduled to vote in relation to this, however the vote has been pushed back (not sure of reschedule yet) we are requesting your support on behalf of our members for amendment 479 that calls for the re-introduction of the €150 exemption for low-risk e-money. Gift cards with a maximum storage amount of €150 shouldn’t need to have customer identification requirements. The end of such exemption would create significant “Know Your Customer” challenges for these gifts and::Without the re-introduction of the €150 exemption, Article 58 of the current EC Proposal, would require small shops issuing gift cards to carry out a customer identification (both for the person purchasing the cards and the person who the card is donated to). This is impractical, and will discourage people from buying them.
Person primarily responsible for lobbyin: Brian O'Farrell & Board of County Carlow Chamber
